awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Collaborative Research: Energy Efficient Millimeter Wave Cellular Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The millimeter wave (mmWave) frequencies and other bands above 6 GHz are a new and promising frontier for cellular wireless communications and the focus of the fifth-generation (5G) standardization efforts.  Due to the massive available bandwidths, the mmWave frequencies offer the possibility of orders of magnitude greater capacity than current cellular systems in the highly congested bands below 3 GHz.  However, a key challenge in realizing mmWave mobile cellular networks is energy consumption. Mobile devices and small-cell access points must operate under highly-constrained power budgets, and developing mmWave systems within these power limits is a formidable task.  This project will investigate energy consumption from a system's perspective to address the issues in an integrated and coherent manner.  The project will develop mathematical models for understanding energy and performance tradeoffs.  New technologies for the radio frequency (RF) circuits, antenna array system, signal processing, and network protocols will be jointly developed to optimize performance and deliver energy-efficient mmWave devices.

The research work will pursue four key thrusts: Thrust 1 will seek to understand the fundamental relation between throughput, processing power, and spectral emission constraints, and optimizes this tradeoff by dynamically controlling key energy drivers including bandwidth, quantization resolution, antenna architecture, and waveform selection. This is combined with novel energy-aware scheduling policies and signal processing techniques.  Thrust 2 will focus on idle mode power savings and associated problems of energy-efficient directional channel estimation and delay in dynamic environments.  Thrust 3 will develop fundamental circuits technologies that enable Thrusts 1 and 2, in particular the novel techniques for both high-efficiency power amplifiers and low-power fully digital RF transceivers.  Thrust 4 will obtain the necessary channel models and build circuit prototypes to validate the concepts in Thrusts 1 to 3.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Broad commercialization of millimeter-wave beamformers requires low-power consumption across an array of elements. The goal of the project is to demonstrate high-efficiency radio-frequency integrated circuits for digital transmit beamforming arrays at 28 GHz, a common band for 5G and future connectivity technologies. Our project investigates power amplifier (PA) techniques that operate with high-average efficiency based on outphasing modulation. Additionally, we are investigating transceiver techniques that allow high-efficiency PAs to be integrated with low-noise receivers in a single integrated circuit. Our original objective was to demonstrate a 28-GHz outphasing transmitter that can operate with an average efficiency exceeding 35% and a low-noise receiver that achieves a noise figure of 2 dB. Additionally, we sought to improve the output power and linearity of the PA for digital beamformers.

During the course of the project, we invented a new load modulation technique for high efficiency under back-off power conditions called passive outphasing modulation and derived the basic theoretical framework for this circuitry. With our new insight into passive load modulation, we investigated methods to use this load modulation network as a T/R switch and substantially simplify the front-end modulation required in a millimeter-wave array. The loss of the passive load modulation network must remain under 1 dB in the receive mode to offer acceptable noise figure.

To understand the practical features of the invention, we investigated the passive outphasing load modulation approach in CMOS SOI and Gallium Nitride technologies. The intellectual contribution was to establish whether a practical switched load network required by the proposed invention could be realized using a combination of the device technologies as switches and the back-end-of-the-line (BEOL) of either of these processes.  We leveraged Win Semiconductor?s NP15 GaN process and GlobalFoundries 45RFSOI process to realize a PA with a switchable load network. The load network is constructed from transmission line elements that can be tapped at different points to change the impedance presented to the PA. In theory, the low loss of the network would enable peak class-B output power under different bias conditions. However, the critical feature of the approach is the loss associated with the switch, a feature common to many switched approaches. For this reason, the comparison of the GaN, which offers high-power handling switches, and CMOS SOI which offers some of the best Ron-Coff products for solid state technology were studied. Moreover, we discovered that GaN HEMTs and CMOS SOI have different requirements for matching networks when comparing the 6-dB backoff and peak efficiency.

We taped out the first passive outphasing load modulated power amplifier at 28 GHz using the NP15 GaN process technology. The circuit uses a class B power amplifier designed to operate at 2 watts of output power and a 3-state load control that can be used to adjust the impedance presented to the power amplifier. The simulated performance indicates a peak PAE of 40% and a 6 dB backoff PAE of 30% at 0.5 W which would be a record for load modulated power amplifiers operating at this band. We have also taped out the 45RFSOI CMOS SOI PA operating 28 GHz that is simulated to deliver 100 mW at 45% peak PAE and a 6-dB backoff PAE of 32%.

The proposed research has exposed not only graduate students but also undergraduate researchers to a variety of skills to evaluate modern radio/wireless access techniques for high-efficiency circuit design as well as to understand the relationship between communication systems, circuit design, and device characteristics. Students have been challenged by a variety of issues related to the design of RFICs and DSP techniques for RF bands. Furthermore, students have been involved with IC design, fabrication, and testing and consequently will be exposed to a broad set of marketable skills. The project has trained 3 graduate students and one undergraduate student over the course of the program. We have published 2 journal papers and 4 conference papers.
